description: The verb is possibly derived from gut (“belly”) +‎ -le (frequentative suffix), perhaps influenced by guzzle (“to drink or eat quickly, voraciously, or to excess; to gulp down; to swallow greedily, continually, or with gusto”).
The noun is derived from the verb.

entries.meaning: One who eats voraciously; a glutton.
examples: Synonyms: gorger, gourmandizer, guttler; see also Thesaurus:glutton

entries.meaning: (obsolete, rare) Something which is eaten voraciously.

verbs.description: guttle (third-person singular simple present guttles, present participle guttling, simple past and past participle guttled) (archaic or Britain, dialectal)

entries.meaning: (transitive) Often followed by down or up: to swallow (something) greedily; to gobble, to guzzle.
examples: Synonyms: ingurgitate, scarf, scoff, wolf down; see also Thesaurus:eat

description: Borrowed from Scots guttle, from gut (“to eviscerate”) + -le (frequentative suffix).

verbs.description: guttle (third-person singular simple present guttles, present participle guttling, simple past and past participle guttled)

entries.meaning: (transitive, Britain, dialectal, Scotland) To remove the guts or entrails from (a person or an animal); to disembowel, to eviscerate, to gut.

description: Origin unknown; possibly imitative of water bubbling or gurgling.

verbs.description: guttle (third-person singular simple present guttles, present participle guttling, simple past and past participle guttled)

entries.meaning: (intransitive, Northern England) To make a bubbling sound; to gurgle.
